properties.media:imagetext:
Mr. Morgan and will tell you all about it. I warn you not to
believe more than half she says.
The show out here was going along beautifully up to the time the
Japs shot Woods down and I had visions of
getting out of the red
before the end of the year. It was too good to las t.
Not having a regular Clipper service just now, while bad in many
ways, has
been a help to me in others. It has
enabled me to
postpone
and procrastinate on katers letters that should have been written
sooner but
which for some raason I have not felt like writing.
When I
first
got here I caught a cold which I could not shake off
had to go to bed for three days. Then I discovered that when Danny
Collinsput in a bridge for me two years ago the tooth he pulled
had broken
and Danny had left the root in.
I am still under
construction with that.
Also
I developed some ear trouble and
finally went to a doctor who discovered I had two small boils down
inside my ear close to the ear drums
It was not important but it
hurt like
the deuce.
I was worse than Jonah and Lazarus but all
of
these served one very excellent purpose that made them worbh while.
They
acted as a counter irritant that enabled me to view with
complete
indifference the numerous foolish proposals of the Minstry
Of Communications and others.
The doctor and the dentis both say
they will be through with me
this week so I guess
I will
soon be
wearing that worried look again.
Royal Leonard, who got married here Saturday, has left the General.
There was no hard feeling. The madame gave him two beautiful letters
one of
recommendation and one of thanks for his services.
He xants
was coming to work for CNAC and still wants to but on account of
restricted flying I am not sure we need him.
I am to let him know
definitely the end of this month.
I wish there were some way we could
transfer Sharp to PAA, he has earned it, so as to make room for
Leonard here.
Leonard is just about as good as Sharp and so good
that I would like to see him in the PAA organization somewhere.
I
would like
to see
Sharp get a chance on the big equipment with PAA
and he ought to
start now in some place where he can begin training.
Well I guess it is no use butting my head against that stone wall.
In a recent letter you said you planned to come
out here in the near
future. I certainly hope you carry this idea out. Please give my
best to Mrs. Bixby and all the family.
Sincerely,
Aarly
properties.wof:name: correspondence: William L. Bond to Harold M. Bixby
